abstract.p: Letter from Tsvi Meidav says contrary to Alan S Blinder's opinion in Oct 22 Op-Ed, carbon dioxide emissions have been reduced successfully through taxation of polluters in countries like Norway, Sweden and Germany (S)

block.p: Alan S. Blinder (Op-Ed, Oct. 22) recommends tradable credits as a mechanism to efficiently reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the atmosphere, a cause of global warming. He believes that command-and-control techniques would be clumsy.

Alan S. Blinder (Op-Ed, Oct. 22) recommends tradable credits as a mechanism to efficiently reduce carbon dioxide emissions in the atmosphere, a cause of global warming. He believes that command-and-control techniques would be clumsy.

However, some European countries, like Norway, Sweden and Germany, have reduced carbon dioxide emissions significantly by taxing polluters and providing incentives for clean energy sources and conservation. A bill before the Minnesota Legislature would impose a tax of $50 per ton of carbon and redistribute much of the revenue in reduced payroll and property taxes.

Tax revenue and the tradable-credits approach combined could act to reduce pollution while protecting economic stability. And the remaining portion of these monies could be used for research and development of clean energy technologies.

The Energy Department's support for such research and development has resulted in a continuing drop in the cost of renewable energy production. As a result, renewable energy is nearly competitive with fossil-based electricity.
The writer is president of a company that develops electricity from geothermal sources.
